| seating_capacity = 36,000{{cite web|last1=Fowles|first1=Shane|title=Simonds Stadium capacity: Geelong Cats reveal capacity crowd is 34,000|url=http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/sport/afl/simonds-stadium-capacity-geelong-cats-reveal-capacity-crowd-is-34000/news-story/be80a770962e1e6395539df74069277f|website=Geelong Advertiser|accessdate=20 August 2017}} | record_attendance = 49,109 (30 August 1952 Geelong v [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]]) | embedded = {{Infobox cricket ground | embed = yes | country = Australia | last used = | seating_capacity = | home club = | county club = | end1 = | end2 = | international = yes | firsttestdate = | firsttestyear = | firsttesthome = | firsttestaway = | lasttestdate = | lasttestyear = | lasttesthome = | lasttestaway = | onlytestdate = | onlytestyear = | onlytesthome = | onlytestaway = | firstodidate = | firstodiyear = | firstodihome = | firstodiaway = | lastodidate = | lastodiyear = | lastodihome = | lastodiaway = | onlyodidate = | onlyodiyear = | onlyodihome = | onlyodiaway = | firstt20idate = | firstt20iyear = | firstt20ihome = | firstt20iaway = | lastt20idate = | lastt20iyear = | lastt20ihome = | lastt20iaway = | onlyt20idate = 19 February | onlyt20iyear = 2017 | onlyt20ihome = Australia | onlyt20iaway = Sri Lanka | year1 = | club1 = | year2 = | club2 = | date = 19 February | year = 2017 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/ground/56402.html Cricinfo }} }} '''Kardinia Park''' (also known as '''GMHBA Stadium''' due to [[naming rights]]) is a sporting and entertainment venue located within [[Kardinia Park]], [[South Geelong, Victoria|South Geelong]], in the [[Australia]]n [[States and territories of Australia|state]] of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. The stadium, which is owned and operated by the [[Kardinia Park Stadium Trust]], is the [[Home (sports)|home]] ground of the [[Geelong Football Club]]. The capacity of Kardinia Park is 34,000, making it the largest-capacity Australian stadium in a regional city (i.e., outside a capital city).{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/AFL/comments/6h3hwr/simonds_stadium_capacity_geelong_cats_reveal/|title=Simonds Stadium capacity: Geelong Cats reveal capacity is 34,000, not 36,000|work=Reddit & Geelong Advertiser|date=13 June 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170616141522/https://www.reddit.com/r/AFL/comments/6h3hwr/simonds_stadium_capacity_geelong_cats_reveal/|archivedate=16 June 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Australian rules football== ===Early years=== Football has been played on Kardinia Park since the 19th century,{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne|date=29 September 1884|page=7|title=Football}} and prior to the 1940s, Kardinia Park was the secondary football venue in the city of Geelong; [[Corio Oval]] was the primary venue, and the [[Geelong Football Club]] played its [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]] games at that venue until 1940. Kardinia Park served as the home ground for the [[Geelong Association Football Club|Geelong (A.) Football Club]] in the [[Victorian Football League|Victorian Football Association]] from 1922{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne|date=3 December 1921|title=Football – turning the tables|author=J.W.|volume=CXI|issue=2905}} until 1925, before that club moved to the Western Oval in [[Geelong West, Victoria|Geelong West]];{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne|date=7 January 1926|page=11|title=Football – New Association clubs}} local and district football was played regularly on the ground. The Geelong Football Club began playing its home games at Kardinia Park in 1941 after Corio Oval was commandeered by the military during [[World War II]], and it became its permanent home venue thereafter. ===Recent history=== On 23 May 2002, Kardinia Park hosted a visit from the [[Dalai Lama]], who again visited the stadium in June 2007. [[File:Aerial perspective of Kardinia Park Stadium with South Geelong station.jpg|thumb|left|Aerial perspective of Kardinia Park Stadium with South Geelong train station]] Kardinia Park is regarded as a proverbial graveyard for teams playing against Geelong, which has an especially good record at the ground in recent years. Geelong did not lose a single match played at the venue between 26 August 2007 and 27 August 2011. Geelong's [[Jimmy Bartel]] credited the home field advantage to the fact that Geelong is one of the few clubs which practices on the same field that it plays on.{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/all-power-to-the-cats-on-home-turf-20110410-1d9cn.html|title=All Power to the Cats on home turf |date=11 April 2011|publisher=[[The Age]]|accessdate=2001-04-11}} On 22 June 2011, it was announced the stadium would have a new name in 2012. After 10 years as naming rights sponsor of Skilled Stadium, [[Skilled Group]] decided to relinquish these rights as of 31 October 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.gfc.com.au/geelongnews/newsarticle/tabid/3933/newsid/116807/default.aspx|title=Cats seek new name for home|work=Tom Peeters|date=22 June 2011|publisher=www.gfc.com.au|accessdate=2011-06-24}} Previous names of the stadium as results of sponsorship deals have been Skilled Stadium, [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell Stadium]] and Baytec Stadium; however it was only called Baytec Stadium for less than two months, and only one pre-season match was played there under the name. The stadium is nicknamed "The Cattery" by the club's supporters. Floodlights were installed prior to the [[2013 AFL season]], and the venue staged its first night match during the season.{{cite web|url=http://www.aeol.com.au/databases/news/simonds_stadium_lights_up_without_a_hitch.php|title=Simonds Stadium lights up without a hitch|work=AEOL|date=5 July 2013}} In its current layout Kardinia Park consists of the following seating areas: the Reg Hickey Stand, Players Stand, Premiership Stand, Brownlow Stand, Ford Stand/Fred Flanagan Room and the Gary Ablett Terrace, with the latter containing the main standing room section.{{cite web|url=https://www.kardiniapark.vic.gov.au/the-stadium/seating-plans|title=Kardinia Park Seating Plans|date=1 May 2017|work=Kardinia Park Stadium Trust}} ==Association football (soccer)== [[File:Kardinia Park January 2016 Melbourne Victory Central Coast Mariners.jpg|thumb|right|400px|[[A-League]] match between [[Melbourne Victory]] and [[Central Coast Mariners]], January 2016]][[Association football]] (soccer) team [[Melbourne Victory FC]] occasionally plays at Kardinia Park. After a seven-year gap between their first match, a [[2007 A-League Pre-Season Challenge Cup]] match against [[Newcastle Jets]] and their second, a [[2014 AFC Champions League qualifying play-off]] against Thai side [[Muangthong United F.C.|Muangthong United]], the ground hosted its first-ever [[A-League]] premiership match in 2015 when Victory played [[Perth Glory FC]] in Round 14 of the [[2014–15 A-League]] season with an attendance of 21,289 as the first match of a three-year deal to bring one Victory fixture per season to Geelong.[http://www.foxsports.com.au/football/a-league/opening-month-of-aleague-season-10-features-a-series-of-blockbuster-matches/story-e6frf4gl-1226951582385 Opening month of A-League season 10 features a series of blockbuster matches], ''Fox Sports Australia'', 12 June 2014 The second match drew 14,268 fans to an exciting six-goal, come-from-behind draw by the Victory against [[Central Coast Mariners FC|Central Coast Mariners]] in January 2016,[http://www.melbournevictory.com.au/article/central-coast-melbourne-victory-play-out-a-league-classic/ojuswhyomx121t6lbt9lbw2xq Central Coast, Victory play out A-League classic] Football Federation Australia official website, John Greco, 8 January 2016 while the third was held on 2 January 2017 with [[Newcastle Jets FC|Newcastle Jets]] as the visiting team, when a crowd of 14,081 witnessed [[Besart Berisha]] overtake [[Archie Thompson]]'s all-time A-League scoring record in a 4–2 win for the Victory.[http://www.melbournevictory.com.au/matchcentre/Melbourne-Victory-v-Newcastle-Jets/854389?matchreport#widget-match-day-tabs Record for Berisha as Victory trounce Jets] Melbourne Victory Official Website, John Greco, 2 January 2017 Victory and the stadium trust agreed to extend the deal by two more years in 2017.[http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/sport/localfooty/geelongs-kardinia-park-to-host-more-melbourne-victory-aleague-games/news-story/54490e97668373e1dbbea6f333fa63f6 Geelong’s Kardinia Park to host more Melbourne Victory A-League games], [[Geelong Advertiser]], Shane Fowles, 20 June 2017 [[UEFA Champions League|European Champions League]] finalists [[Atlético Madrid]] played [[Melbourne Victory FC|Melbourne Victory]] in a friendly match at the stadium on 31 July 2016. Melbourne Victory won 1–0.[http://www.melbournevictory.com.au/article/victory-to-play-atletico-de-madrid-in-geelong/6oh8w9wihbbt16myz63jna41o Victory to play Atlético de Madrid in Geelong] Melbourne Victory official website, 16 June 2016 The stadium has also played host to one full international match on 30 December 2014, a pre-tournament friendly between [[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]] and [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]] prior to the [[2015 AFC Asian Cup]] hosted by Australia, which ended as a 4–1 win for Bahrain.[http://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/afc-asian-cup/bahrain-put-four-past-saudi-arabia-in-geelong-20141230-12fm2x.html Bahrain put four past Saudi Arabia in Geelong] 31 December 2014, Roy Ward, [[Sydney Morning Herald]] Kardinia Park was included in the [[Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid]], with a proposed upgrade to 44,000 seats analogous to the later mooted stage 5 of redevelopment, with the new multi tiered stand stretching all the way from the southern end, around the western side and the northern Ablett stand, however the bid lost out to Qatar.{{cite web|title=AUSTRALIAN WORLD CUP STADIUMS|url=http://www.austadiums.com/australiaworldcup/|publisher=austadiums.com|accessdate=12 April 2014}} ==Other uses== During the late 1920s and early 1930s when [[Motorcycle speedway]] was becoming popular throughout Australia, Kardinia Park was home to a dirt track speedway known as the Geelong Velodrome. The Velodrome hosted the inaugural [[Victorian Individual Speedway Championship|Victorian Solo Speedway Championship]] in 1926/27 and followed up with the second championship held in 1927/28. Both championships were won by [[Billy Pilgrim (speedway rider)|Billy Pilgrim]]. ==Cricket== In 2016, it was announced that international cricket would be played at the ground for the first time. The ground hosted second [[Twenty20 International|T20 International]] between [[Sri Lankan cricket team in Australia in 2016–17|Australia and Sri Lanka]] on February 19.{{cite web | url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/australia-v-sri-lanka-2016-17/engine/match/1001351.html | title=Sri Lanka tour of Australia, 2nd T20I: Australia v Sri Lanka at Geelong, Feb 19, 2017 | publisher=ESPNcricinfo | accessdate=19 February 2017}} The ground witnessed memorable match between two nations, where Sri Lanka won the match by 2 wickets at the end. Sri Lanka chased 173 runs at the last ball of the match, where [[Asela Gunaratne]] smashed 46-ball unbeaten 84 runs to seal the match and series for Sri Lanka.{{cite web | url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/australia-v-sri-lanka-2016-17/content/story/1083287.html | title=Gunaratne 84* caps stunning series win for Sri Lanka | publisher=ESPNcricinfo | accessdate=19 February 2017}} On 3 January 2018 the ground hosted a [[Women's Big Bash League]] and [[Big Bash League]] double header with the [[Melbourne Renegades]] taking on the [[Sydney Sixers]] with the Renegades winning in both matches. The ground has been confirmed as one of the venues to be used in the [[2020 ICC T20 World Cup]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/media-releases/604922|title=Eight cities throughout Australia to host ICC World T20 2020|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en}}. ==Redevelopments== [[File:Aerial perspective of Kardinia Park stadium.jpg|thumb|Aerial perspective of Kardinia Park stadium. Taken August 2018.]] A {{A$}}28 million redevelopment of the ground was announced in 2003, with A$13.5 million in funding from the [[Government of Victoria|Victorian Government]], A$4.5 million from the Geelong Football Club, and A$2 million from the [[Australian Football League|AFL]]. The redeveloped ground was opened on 1 May 2005 during the first home game of the 2005 season which includes a new western entry and membership area, as well as a new five-level grandstand with a capacity of approximately 6,000 spectators on the eastern side of the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums_redevelopment.php?id=101|title=Simonds Stadium Redevelopment|date=1 January 2017|work=Austadiums|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519064604/http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums_redevelopment.php?id=101|archivedate=19 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dpcd.vic.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/132549/Part_4_Annual_Report.pdf|title=Department for Victorian Communities 2004–05 Annual Report|date=1 July 2005|work=Victorian Government|quote=Refer to pp. 57|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519064448/http://www.dpcd.vic.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/132549/Part_4_Annual_Report.pdf|archivedate=19 May 2017}} A favourite for the honour of the naming of the new stand was [[Bob Davis (Australian rules footballer)|Bob Davis]], coach of the Cats' premiership side in 1963. On 15 June 2005, [[City of Greater Geelong]] councillors granted the club its wish to change the name of the new eastern stand to the [[Reg Hickey]] Stand, while the southern stand became the [[Doug Wade]] Stand. The northern terrace became known as the [[Gary Ablett Sr.|Gary Ablett]] Terrace while the western gate was renamed the Bob Davis Gate. In September 2007, Skilled Stadium received a further total of A$25 million towards the rebuilding of the Ross Drew Stand on the south western side of the ground. Funding for the project included A$14 million from the Federal Government and A$6 million from the Victorian Government.{{cite web|url=https://ministers.treasury.gov.au/DisplayDocs.aspx?doc=pressreleases/2007/097.htm&pageID=003&min=phc&Year=&DocType=0|title=Geelong Scores a Win with Funding for Skilled Stadium|date=21 September 2007|work=Australian Government|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519065258/https://ministers.treasury.gov.au/DisplayDocs.aspx?doc=pressreleases%2F2007%2F097.htm&pageID=003&min=phc&Year=&DocType=0|archivedate=19 May 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} The new stand, known as the Premiership Stand, features seating for 4,500 supporters, including up to 800 corporate guests on match days. The stand opened on 10 April 2010 and was officially unveiled in round four of the [[2010 AFL season]], coinciding with the unveiling of the 2009 premiership flag.{{cite web|url=http://www.de-air.com.au/completed-projects-sports-leisure/skilled-stadium-premiership-stand|title=Skilled Stadium Premiership Stand (d&e)|work=de-air.com.au|date=1 January 2011|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170519071157/http://www.de-air.com.au/completed-projects-sports-leisure/skilled-stadium-premiership-stand|archivedate=19 May 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.watpac.com.au/project/skilled-stadium-premiership-stand/|title=Skilled Stadium Premiership Stand (Watpac Limited)|date=1 January 2011|work=Watpac.com.au|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170519071040/https://www.watpac.com.au/project/skilled-stadium-premiership-stand/|archivedate=19 May 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} A$50,000 was also spent on a new 600-seat temporary stand between the Reg Hickey and Doug Wade stands.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} In May 2009 it was revealed that the City of Greater Geelong as stadium owner had approached a number of Melbourne-based AFL clubs discussing the financial advantages of playing home games at the ground. The ground could see clubs earning A$30 a patron at Skilled Stadium, compared to A$7 earned at [[Docklands Stadium|Etihad Stadium]] in Melbourne. The Geelong Football Club had first floated Skilled Stadium as a potential home game venue for Melbourne clubs in 2006.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} In April 2011, plans for the third stage of redevelopment were revealed. Under the plans, the Doug Wade stand at the southern end of the stadium was pulled down at the end of the [[2011 AFL season]]. The works included the demolition of the old Doug Wade stand and the construction of a new 9,000 (approx.) seat Southern Grandstand. The new Grandstand also included:{{cite web|url=http://www.wtpartnership.com/sector/simonds-stadium-stage-3-redevelopment-lighting-upgrade-projects-geelong/|title=Simonds Stadium Stage 3 Redevelopment|date=1 January 2014|work=WTPartnership|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170519073339/http://www.wtpartnership.com/sector/simonds-stadium-stage-3-redevelopment-lighting-upgrade-projects-geelong/|archivedate=19 May 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} * Improved spectator amenities * A Community Wellness and Education Centre – a purpose built training facility for community sporting groups * A new 'Past Players' room * Constructed concurrently to the Grandstand were five new light towers which comply with Australian Broadcast requirements. The new light towers allow the ground to host night AFL and cricket matches. The redevelopment saw the stadium increase in capacity to 34,500. The redevelopment cost $33 million, of which $11.7 million was spent on the new lighting. [[Image:Kardinia Park at night, Aug 2014.jpg|right|thumb|360px|An AFL night match at Simonds Stadium (2014)]] Significant miscalculations were made with respect to the budget required for the stage 3 redevelopment and consequently several aspects of the plans were scaled back by the Geelong Football Club in November 2011, including the removal of a proposed supporters lounge and decreasing capacity by 1,000 seats.{{cite web|url=http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/article/2011/11/23/292851_news.html|title=Stadium renovations still on track|work=Geelong Advertiser|date=23 November 2011|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120917183804/http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/article/2011/11/23/292851_news.html|archivedate=17 September 2012|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} The new grandstand was named the Players Stand in August 2012 and from 1 November 2011, the venue became known as Simonds Stadium, after homebuilding group Simonds Homes signed a five-year naming rights deal.{{cite web|url=http://www.austadiums.com/news/news.php?id=490|title=Simonds Stadium new name for Kardinia Park|work=Austadiums|date=4 October 2011|archivedate=19 May 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519083901/http://www.austadiums.com/news/news.php?id=490}} The new Players Stand was officially opened on 1 June 2013, prior to Geelong's first proper home match of the [[2013 AFL season]] against [[Gold Coast Football Club|Gold Coast]]. The match was the first to be played under the new floodlights and was played before 30,082 fans, the largest crowd at the stadium at that time since the first stage of the re-development.{{cite web|url=http://www.geelongcats.com.au/news/2013-06-01/talking-points-cats-and-suns|title=Talking points: Cats and Suns|date=1 June 2013|work=Geelong Cats|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519075613/http://www.geelongcats.com.au/news/2013-06-01/talking-points-cats-and-suns|archivedate=19 May 2017}} In September 2014, then Victorian opposition leader [[Daniel Andrews]] promised $70 million to complete stage four of the upgrade of the oval in the [[Australian Labor Party|Labor Party's]] successful election campaign. The stage funded involves demolishing the Brownlow and Jennings stands and replacing them with a new stand, for a total capacity of 36,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/news/geelong/labor-pledges-100-million-on-upgrades-for-simonds-stadium-and-gpac/story-fnjuhovy-1227052255475|title=Labor pledges $100 million on upgrades for Simonds Stadium and GPAC|work=Geelong Advertiser|date=9 September 2014|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170519080024/http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/news/geelong/labor-pledges-100-million-on-upgrades-for-simonds-stadium-and-gpac/news-story/e24ed8b77acdf0124790ac57958f4333|archivedate=19 May 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} The new stand, eventually named the Brownlow Stand (in honour of the club's [[Brownlow Medal]] winners and Mr [[Chas Brownlow|Charles Brownlow]]) was opened on 18 May 2017. The new stand features seating for 6,500 people, improved media facilities, a new 1000-seat function centre, merchandise store, café, an enhanced football department and the Sunrise Centre, a community facility providing rehabilitation for people returning to the [[Occupational injury|workforce following serious injury]].{{cite web|url=http://www.geelongcats.com.au/news/2017-05-18/brownlow-stand-officially-opened|title=Brownlow Stand officially opened|work=Geelong Cats|date=18 May 2017|archivedate=19 May 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519081131/http://www.geelongcats.com.au/news/2017-05-18/brownlow-stand-officially-opened}} The total cost of the fourth stage of redevelopment was $91 million, of which $75m came from the [[Victorian Government]], $6m from the [[City of Greater Geelong]], $6 million from the Geelong Football Club and $4 million from the [[Australian Football League|AFL]]. The total capacity of Kardinia Park after the stage 4 redevelopment is technically 36,000;{{cite web|url=http://www.austadiums.com/news/news.php?id=589|title=Kardinia Park: New Brownlow Stand unveiled|date=18 May 2017|work=Austadiums|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170616141820/http://www.austadiums.com/news/news.php?id=589|archivedate=16 June 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} however, given the way the stadium is configured for AFL matches, its capacity is said to be unable to exceed 34,000. During 2016 laws were passed by the [[Parliament of Victoria|Victorian Parliament]] for management of the stadium to be taken over by a state appointed [[Kardinia Park Stadium Trust]] in line with practices at other major venues in the state.{{cite web|url=http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/news/geelong/kardinia-park-stadium-trust-passes-parliament-now-on-search-for-chief-executive/news-story/4449bb1681fa04af040e7eae275b0670|title=Kardinia Park Stadium Trust passes Parliament, now on search for chief executive|work=Geelong Advertiser|date=27 February 2016|archivedate=19 May 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170519081630/http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/news/geelong/kardinia-park-stadium-trust-passes-parliament-now-on-search-for-chief-executive/news-story/4449bb1681fa04af040e7eae275b0670|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} Prior to this the venue had been owned and operated by the [[City of Greater Geelong]], which now maintains and manages the broader [[Kardinia Park]] precinct, though not the actual stadium itself.{{cite web|url=http://www.geelongaustralia.com.au/parks/item/kardinia.aspx|title=Kardinia Park|work=City of Greater Geelong|date=1 January 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170503075516/http://www.geelongaustralia.com.au/parks/item/kardinia.aspx|archivedate=3 May 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} In April 2017, the Victorian Government announced an investment of $3.9 million in the upcoming state [[Government budget|budget]] to fund the planning and design stage for Stage 5 of the redevelopment. The proposed redevelopment would be the final part of the more than decade-long process to increase the capacity of Kardinia Park to 40,000 and will result in the Ford Stand and Gary Ablett Terrace being removed for the new stand to ring around the remaining open-air section of the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.kardiniapark.vic.gov.au/2017/04/media-release-2|title=Media Release: Labor Kick Starts Next Upgrade of Geelong's Kardinia Park|work=Kardinia Park Stadium Trust|date=27 April 2017|archivedate=19 May 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170519083508/https://www.kardiniapark.vic.gov.au/2017/04/media-release-2|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kardiniapark.vic.gov.au/2017/04/media-release|title=Media Release: Kardinia Park Stadium Trust welcomes stadium budget boost|work=Kardinia Park Stadium Trust|date=27 April 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170519083106/https://www.kardiniapark.vic.gov.au/2017/04/media-release|archivedate=19 May 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} In January 2018, the stadium was commercially named as [[GMHBA Limited|GMHBA]] Stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/2016-11-21/cats-set-for-stadium-name-change-in-new-deal|title=Stadium name change for Cats in new deal|date=21 November 2016|work=AFL.com.au|archivedate=19 May 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519084435/http://www.afl.com.au/news/2016-11-21/cats-set-for-stadium-name-change-in-new-deal}} ==Hosted events== *[[Australian Football League]] Away team |- | Australian Rules Football || 49,109 || 30 August 1952 || Geelong Cats || Carlton |- | Cricket (Domestic T20) || 23,586 || 3 January 2018 || Melbourne Renegades || Sydney Sixers |- | Association Football || 21,289 || 2 January 2015 || Melbourne Victory || Perth Glory |- | Cricket (International T20) || 13,647 || 19 February 2017 || Australia || Sri Lanka |- | Rugby Union || 8,000 || 2012 || Melbourne Rebels || Waikato Chiefs |} * [http://afltables.com/afl/crowds/vn_kardinia_park.html Sources] ==VFL/AFL records== '''Players''' * Most games played: [[Ian Nankervis]] ({{AFL Gee}}), 325 * Most goals kicked: [[Doug Wade]] ({{AFL Gee}}/{{AFL NM}}), 413 * Most goals kicked in a match: [[Doug Wade]] ({{AFL Gee}}), 13.2 (80) vs. {{AFL NM}}, 14 August 1971 * Most disposals in a match: [[Tony Shaw]] ({{AFL Col}}), 48 vs. {{AFL Gee}}, 12 May 1984 '''Teams''' * Highest score: {{AFL Gee}} 37.11 (233) defeated {{AFL Mel}} 7.5 (47), 30 July 2011 * Lowest score: {{AFL SM}} 1.9 (15) defeated by {{AFL Gee}} 8.9 (57), 8 August 1964 * Biggest margin: {{AFL Gee}} defeated {{AFL Mel}}, 186 points, 30 July 2011 * Longest winning streak: {{AFL Gee}}, 29 games, 2008–2011 Last updated: 25 May 2015.http://afltables.com/afl/venues/kardinia_park.html ==Dimensions== *Length – 170m *Width – 115m *Goals run north to south [http://www.afl.com.au/tickets/venues/simonds-stadium/ Source] The field is the narrowest playing field used for AFL games; however, many other venues are much shorter (with [[The Gabba]] being the shortest). ==Naming rights sponsors== *1999–2001: [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] *2001: [[Baytec]] *2001–11: [[Skilled Group|Skilled]] *2012–17: [[Simonds Homes|Simonds]] *2018–present: [[GMHBA Limited|GMHBA]] {{cite web|url=http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/sport/afl/geelong-cats-simonds-stadium-home-ground-to-be-renamed-gmhba-stadium/news-story/9019ba3dd19066586b4fca8ec5435563|title=Geelong Cats’ Simonds Stadium home ground to be renamed GMHBA Stadium|last=Auciello|first=Michael|date=27 February 2016|publisher=[[Geelong Advertiser]]|accessdate=4 May 2018}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *{{Austadiums|101}} *[http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums_redevelopment.php?id=101 Kardinia Park Redevelopment] – Austadiums.com *[http://www.aroundthegrounds.bellestorie.com/kardinia/kardinia.html "Around the Grounds" – Web Documentary – Kardinia Park] *[http://www.kardiniapark.vic.gov.au/ Official Kardinia Park Stadium website] {{Geelong Football Club}} {{AFL grounds}} {{AFL Women's grounds}} {{A-League stadiums}} {{NRC Grounds}} {{Big Bash League Cricket grounds}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kardinia Park (Stadium)}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1941]] [[Category:Australian Football League grounds]] [[Category:Victorian Football League grounds]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Geelong]] [[Category:Geelong Football Club]] [[Category:World Series Cricket venues]] [[Category:Sport in Geelong]] [[Category:Sports venues in Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Australia]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in Australia]] [[Category:AFL Women's grounds]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Keystone Centre | image = KeystoneCentre.jpg | image_size = 250px | former_names = | location = 1175 18th Street
[[Brandon, Manitoba|Brandon]], [[Manitoba]], R7A 7C5 | coordinates = {{coord|49|49|51|N|99|57|36|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = November 13, 1970 | opened = April 2, 1973{{cite web |title=The Official opening of the Keystone Center occurred on 2nd April 1973|url=http://www.ebrandon.ca/messagethread.aspx?message_id=615729&cat_id=57|work=eBrandon|accessdate=October 18, 2013}} | expanded = 1982, 1992 | owner = Keystone Agricultural & Recreation Centre Inc. | operator = Keystone Agricultural & Recreation Centre Inc. | surface = Multi-surface | construction_cost = [[Canadian dollar|$]]3.4 million{{cite journal |year=1971|title=Work Starts on Brandon, Man. Exhibition Center|journal=Amusement Business|volume=83|issue=3|publisher=Billboard Publications}}
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|3400000|1972}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}) | architect = Ward & Macdonald Associates{{cite news|title=Keystone Centre still on the go|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=1969-04-05|page=18|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-apr-05-1969-569810/}} {{free access}} | capacity = 5,102 ([[Ice hockey|Hockey]])
5,000 ([[Royal Manitoba Winter Fair]]) | tenants = [[Brandon Wheat Kings]] ([[Western Hockey League|WHL]]) (1972–present)
[[Provincial Exhibition of Manitoba]] (1972–present) | website = {{URL|http://www.keystonecentre.com}} }} The '''Keystone Centre''' is a multi-purpose facility located in [[Brandon, Manitoba]]. Its main 5,102-seat arena which is known as Westoba Place is the home of the [[Brandon Wheat Kings]] of the [[Western Hockey League]] and the annual [[Royal Manitoba Winter Fair]]. ==History== The original structure was built in 1973 and was known as the Keystone Centre. It was a joint venture between the City of Brandon, the Government of Manitoba, and the [[Provincial Exhibition of Manitoba]], which organizes the Royal Fair each March. The Keystone Agricultural and Recreation Centre Inc., a non-profit corporation formed by the three parties, owns and operates the complex and grounds. The Provincial Exhibition of Manitoba contributed the original land and assets. The City of Brandon and the Province of Manitoba have agreed to cover any operating deficits of the Keystone Centre. The [[Canad Inns]] hotel replaced the [[Manex Arena]], the former home of the Wheat Kings. The complex underwent through an interior redesign in the summer of 2007. The Keystone Centre also features an exhibition hall for trade shows and agricultural events, two smaller hockey arenas, and the [[Brandon Curling Club]]. On May 1, 2007, Westman Communications Group purchased the [[naming rights]] to the main arena and viewing lounge. Westman Communications Group ended their naming rights to the main arena in October, 2017, and signage was removed in January, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.brandonsun.com/local/westman-communications-group-place-out-as-name-for-keystone-centre-arena-471717084.html|title=Westman Communications Group Place out as name for Keystone Centre arena|date=2018-01-30|website=Brandon Sun|access-date=2018-01-30}} On February 2, 2018, Westoba Credit Union purchased the naming rights to the main arena and viewing lounge.{{cite web|url=http://wheatkings.com/article/keystone-centre-to-become-westoba-place|title=WESTMAN PLACE TO BECOME WESTOBA PLACE|date=2018-02-02|website=Brandon Wheat Kings|access-date=2018-02-02}} ==Events== The Westoba Place hosted the [[2010 Memorial Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://whl.ca/news/?id=10297 |title=Brandon Wheat Kings to host 2010 MasterCard Memorial Cup |accessdate=October 16, 2008 |date=October 16, 2008 |publisher=Western Hockey League |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081021055949/http://www.whl.ca/news/?id=10297 |archivedate=October 21, 2008 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2008/10/15/memorial-cup-brandon.html|title=Brandon wins bid to host 2010 Memorial Cup|accessdate=October 17, 2008|date=October 15, 2008|work=CBC Sports}} Other major events held at the Keystone Centre include the [[1999 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships]] (co-hosted with [[Winnipeg]]), the [[1995 Ford World Men's Curling Championship|1995 Ford Men's]] and [[1995 Ford World Women's Curling Championship|Women's]] [[World Curling Championships]], the [[1982 Labatt Brier]], the [[1993 Scott Tournament of Hearts|1993]] and [[2002 Scott Tournament of Hearts]], the [[1997 Canadian Olympic Curling Trials]], and the [[1994 Air Canada Cup]]. On October 13, 2017, Curling Canada announced that the [[2019 Tim Hortons Brier]] will take place at the Keystone Centre from March 2nd to 10th.{{cite web|url=http://www.curling.ca/blog/2017/10/13/brandon-to-play-host-to-2019-tim-hortons-brier/|title=Brandon to play host to 2019 Tim Hortons Brier |accessdate=April 2, 2018 |date=October 13, 2017 |publisher=Curling Canada}} The Western Canadian Junior "B" Hockey Championship, the [[Keystone Cup]], is named after the Keystone Centre as it was the alternate site used by the original tournament in 1983 that took place in [[Portage la Prairie, Manitoba]]. [[WWE]] held their flagship [[Monday Night Raw]] event on October 23, 1995. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.keystonecentre.com/ Keystone Centre] {{WHL Arenas}} [[Category:1973 establishments in Manitoba]] [[Category:Curling venues in Canada]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Manitoba]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1973]] [[Category:Sports venues in Brandon, Manitoba]] [[Category:Western Hockey League arenas]]

{{infobox country at games | NOC = KGZ | NOCname = [[National Olympic Committee of the Republic of Kyrgyzstan]] | games = Winter Olympics | year = 1994 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = [[Lillehammer]] | competitors = 1 (0 men and 1 woman) | sports = 1 | flagbearer = [[Torkel Engeness]] | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = 1994 | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = {{flagIOC|RU1}} (1900–1912)
{{flagIOC|URS}} (1952–1988)
{{flagIOC|EUN|1992 Summer}} (1992) }} [[Kyrgyzstan]] competed in the [[Winter Olympic Games]] as an independent nation for the first time at the [[1994 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lillehammer]], [[Norway]]. The Kyrgyz team did not arrive in time for the opening ceremony, and the Kyrgyz flag was carried into the Olympic arena by the designated Norwegian translator, [[Torkel Engeness]]. Biathlete [[Yevgeniya Roppel]] was the only competitor in Lillehammer for Kyrgyzstan. == Biathlon == {{main|Biathlon at the 1994 Winter Olympics}} ;Women {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="3"|Final |- !Time !Pen. !Rank |- |rowspan=2|[[Yevgeniya Roppel]] |7.5 km Sprint |align="center"|31:08.0 |align="center"|3 !align="center"|66 |- |15 km Individual |align="center"|1:02:46.6 |align="center"|5 !align="center"|67 |} ==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060622162855/http://www.la84foundation.org/5va/reports_frmst.htm Official Olympic Reports] *[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/KGZ/winter/1994/ sports-reference] {{Nations at the 1994 Winter Olympics}} [[Category:Nations at the 1994 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:Kyrgyzstan at the Winter Olympics by year|1994]] [[Category:1994 in Kyrgyzstani sport]] {{Kyrgyzstan-sport-stub}} {{1994-winter-Olympic-stub}}

Over the course of the game's history, several incidents relating to '''match-fixing in English football''' have taken place.
==19th Century Test match collusion== From 1893–1898, a form of play-offs known as ''test matches'' were used to decide [[promotion and relegation]] between the two divisions of the [[Football League]]. Initially they were direct ties between two teams, but from 1896 a [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] format was used. In the 1898 test matches, earlier results meant [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke]] and [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] went into the final test match knowing a draw would result in promotion for both teams. In their 0–0 draw, the pair made little attempt to hide their collusion. The ''Athletic News'' reported that "the teams could have done without goalkeepers, so anxious were the forwards not to score". The Football League resolved the ensuing scandal by expanding the First Division from 16 to 18 clubs, allowing promotion for all four of the clubs who participated in the test matches. The test match system was then abandoned.<ref>{{cite book|title=League Football and the Men Who Made It|first=Simon|last=Inglis|publisher=Willow Books|year=1988|isbn=0-00-218242-4|pages=43–4}}</ref>
The following season, Burnley's [[Jack Hillman]] offered [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] players £2 each to "take it easy" in a match between the teams. Hillman was suspended for a year for his actions.<ref>{{cite news | title=Roll-call of shame: the history of British match-fixing| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/rollcall-of-shame-the-history-of-british-matchfixing-1611272.html| publisher=Independent | accessdate=5 February 2013| location=London| first=David| last=Aaronovitch| date=15 March 1995}}</ref>
==Billy Meredith bribery suspension== On the final day of the 1904–05 season, [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] played a particularly bad-tempered game, in which a number of fights broke out.<ref>{{cite book |last=James |first=Gary |title=Manchester The City Years |publisher=James Ward |location=Halifax |year=2012 |isbn=978-0-9558127-7-4|page=110}}</ref> Four months later, it emerged that Villa captain [[Alec Leake]] had come forward with an accusation: that City's [[Billy Meredith]] had offered him £10 to allow City to win. The Football Association suspended Meredith until April 1906.<ref>{{cite book |last=Harding |first=John |title=Football Wizard – The Billy Meredith Story |publisher=Robson Books |location=London |year=1998 |isbn=1-86105-137-9|page=110}}</ref> Meredith, who had not been permitted to give evidence at the hearing, protested his innocence.<ref>Harding, ''Football Wizard'', p. 111.</ref> Later, however, while engaged in a dispute with Manchester City over whether he should be paid during his suspension, he spoke out on the matter. He admitted the bribery attempt, but intimated that others were involved, saying "I was only the spokesman of others equally guilty".<ref>Harding, ''Football Wizard'', p. 118.</ref>
==1915 betting scandal== {{main|1915 British football betting scandal}} A 1915 match between [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] aroused suspicions owing to the apparent lack of effort on the part of the Liverpool players. The match finished 2–0 to a relegation-threatened Manchester United.
After the match, [[Flyer (pamphlet)|handbills]] started to appear, alleging that a large amount of money had been bet at odds of 7/1 on a 2–0 win to United.<ref name="Sharpe">{{cite book|last=Sharpe|first=Graham|title=Gambling's Strangest Moments: Extraordinary But True Stories from Over 200 Years of Gambling's History|year=2005|publisher=Robson|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1861058640|pages=370}}</ref> An investigation by [[the Football Association]] was launched and found that players from both sides had been involved in rigging the match: [[Sandy Turnbull]], [[Arthur Whalley]] and [[Enoch West]] of United, and [[Jackie Sheldon]], [[Tom Miller (footballer)|Tom Miller]], [[Bob Pursell (footballer born 1889)|Bob Pursell]] and [[Thomas Fairfoul]] of Liverpool; Sheldon was a former United player himself and was found to be the plot's ringleader. Some players, such as Liverpool's [[Fred Pagnam]] and United's George Anderson refused to take part. Pagnam had threatened to score a goal to ruin the result, and indeed late in the match hit the crossbar, causing his teammates to publicly remonstrate with him.<ref>{{cite book|author=Phillips, Oliver|title=The Golden Boys: A study of Watford's Cult Heroes|publisher=Alpine Press|page=49|year=2001|isbn=0-9528631-6-2}}</ref> He later testified against his team-mates at the FA hearing. At the same hearing, United player Billy Meredith denied any knowledge of the match-fixing, but stated that he became suspicious when none of his teammates would pass the ball to him.<ref>{{cite book|last=Tibballs|first=Geoff|title=Great Sporting Scandals: From Over 200 Years of Sporting Endeavours|year=2003|publisher=Robson Publishing|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1861056869|pages=337}}</ref>
All seven players were banned from playing for life in a decision handed down on 27 December 1915. The FA concluded that it had been a conspiracy by the players alone – no official from either club was found guilty of wrongdoing, and neither club was fined or had points deducted.<ref>{{cite book|last=Holland|first=Peter|title=Swifter Than the Arrow: Wilfred Bartrop, Football and War|year=2008|publisher=Troubador Publishing Ltd|location=United Kingdom|isbn=9781848760684|pages=148}}</ref>
==1964 betting scandal== {{main|1964 British betting scandal}}
==Accrington Stanley–Bury, 2008== Unusual betting patterns were reported for a match between [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] and [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] on the final day of the 2007–08 season. A Football Association investigation resulted in five players, four of whom played for Accrington Stanley and the other for Bury, being charged with betting on a Bury win.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/apr/07/football-betting-accrington-five-charged |title=Five players charged in League Two betting scandal |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=2009-04-07 |accessdate=2013-02-04 |location=London}}</ref> [[Jay Harris (footballer born 1987)|Jay Harris]] was banned from playing for a year, [[David Mannix]] for ten months, [[Robbie Williams (footballer born 1979)|Robert Williams]] and [[Peter Cavanagh]] for eight months, and [[Andrew Mangan]] for five months.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/8162844.stm|title=Four players banned over betting|date=22 July 2009|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/leaguetwo/6004978/Accrington-defender-Peter-Cavanagh-suspended-after-betting-probe.html|title=Accrington's Pater Cavanagh banned for betting on Bury match|date=2009-08-10|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=2013-02-04|location=London}}</ref> Each player was also fined between £2,000–5,000.
==Europol investigation== {{Main|2013 Europol match-fixing investigation}} A [[Europol]] investigation into match-fixing by criminal syndicates published its initial findings in February 2013. Of 380 matches in Europe alleged to be fixed, one took place in England. The match, a [[UEFA Champions League]] tie from the "last three or four years", was not named due to "ongoing judicial proceedings".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21319807|title=Match-fixing: Champions League tie played in England 'was fixed'|date=4 February 2013|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/feb/04/europol-investigation-football-matchfixing|title=Europol: investigators identify 380 fixed football matches|date=4 February 2013|work=The Guardian|accessdate=4 February 2013|location=London}}</ref>
==2013 match fixing scandal== {{Main|2013 English match fixing scandal}} Six people were arrested by the [[National Crime Agency]] in the wake of an investigation by the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' newspaper in November 2013.<ref name="TelegNov">{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/10479667/Football-match-fixing-six-arrested-by-police-investigating-betting-syndicate-as-rigging-hits-British-game.html|title=Football match-fixing: six arrested by police investigating betting syndicate as rigging hits British game|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]''|date=28 November 2013|accessdate=28 November 2013|location=London|first=Claire|last=Newell}}</ref>
==Bibliography==
*Simon Inglis, ''Soccer in the Dock'' (Collins, 1985) {{ISBN|0-00-218162-2}} {{ISBN|978-0-00-218162-4}}
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Match fixing in association football}}

revision.text:
[[File:Franck Junillon 04.jpg|thumb|300px|Mouthguard in contact sport]] [[File:Knirscherschiene.jpg|thumb|An example of a mouthguard used in the treatment of [[bruxism]]]]
A '''mouthguard''' is a protective device for the [[mouth]] that covers the teeth and gums to prevent and reduce injury to the [[teeth]], arches, [[lip]]s and [[Gingiva|gum]]s. A mouthguard is most often used to prevent injury in [[contact sports]], as a treatment for [[bruxism]] or [[Temporomandibular joint disorder|TMD]], or as part of certain dental procedures, such as [[tooth bleaching]] or [[sleep apnea]]. Depending on application, it may also be called a '''mouth protector''', '''mouth piece''', '''gumshield''', '''gumguard''', '''nightguard''', '''occlusal splint''', '''bite splint''', or '''bite plane'''.
==History== The exact origins of the mouthguard are unclear. Most evidence indicates that the concept of a mouthguard was initiated in the sport of [[boxing]]. Originally, boxers fashioned rudimentary mouthguards out of cotton, tape, sponge, or small pieces of wood. Boxers clenched the material between their teeth. These boxers had a hard time focusing on the fight and clenching their teeth at the same time.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Knapik JJ, Marshall SW, Lee RB, Darakjy SS, Jones SB, Mitchener TA, Jones BH | year = 2007 | title = Mouthguards in Sport Activities | doi = 10.2165/00007256-200737020-00003 | journal = Sports Medicine | volume = 37 | issue = 2| page = 120 }}</ref> Since these devices proved impractical, Woolf Krause, a British dentist, began to fashion mouthpieces for boxers in 1892. Krause placed strips of a natural rubber resin, [[gutta-percha]], over the [[maxillary incisors]] of boxers before they entered the ring.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Reed RV | year = 1994 | title = Origin and early history of the dental mouthpiece | doi = 10.1038/sj.bdj.4808485 | journal = British Dental Journal | volume = 176 | issue = | page = 479 }}</ref> Phillip Krause, Woolf Krause’s son, is often credited with the first reusable mouthpiece. Phillip Krause’s invention was highlighted in a 1921 championship fight between [[Jack Britton]] and [[Ted "Kid" Lewis]]. Lewis was a school friend of Krause and the first professional to utilize the new technology, then called a ‘gum shield.’ During the fight, Britton’s manager successfully argued that the mouthpiece was an illegal advantage. Philip Krause was an amateur boxer himself and undoubtedly used his device before 1921.<ref name="Knapik et al., 2007, p. 120">Knapik et al., 2007, p. 120.</ref>
There have been other claims to the invention of the mouthguard as well. In the early 1900s, Jacob Marks created a custom-fitted mouthguard in London.<ref>Pontsa, Peter T. (2008). Mouth Guards Prevent Dental Trauma in Sports. The Dent-Liner 12 (3).</ref> An American dentist, Thomas A. Carlos, also developed a mouth guard at approximately the same time as Krause. Carlos claimed that he made his first mouthpiece in 1916 and later suggested his invention to the United States Olympian Dinnie O’Keefe in 1919. Another dentist from Chicago, E. Allen Franke, also claimed to have made many mouth guards for boxers by 1919.<ref name="Knapik et al., 2007, p. 120"/> The mouthguard’s relevance was again brought to the center of attention in a 1927 boxing match between [[Jack Sharkey]] and [[Mike McTigue]]. McTigue was winning for most of the fight, but a chipped tooth cut his lip, and he was forced to forfeit the match. From that point on, mouthguards were ruled acceptable and soon became commonplace for all boxers.<ref name="Knapik et al., 2007, p. 121">Knapik et al., 2007, p. 121.</ref> In 1930, descriptions of mouthguards first appeared in dental literature. Dr. Clearance Mayer, a dentist and boxing inspector for the [[New York State Athletic Commission]], described how custom mouthguards could be manufactured from impressions using wax and rubber. Steel springs were even recommended to reinforce soft materials.<ref name="Knapik et al., 2007, p. 121"/>
In 1947, a Los Angeles dentist, Rodney O. Lilyquist, made a breakthrough by using transparent acrylic resin to form what he termed an "acrylic splint". Molded to fit unobtrusively over the upper or lower teeth, the acrylic mouthguard was a distinct improvement over the thick mouthguard worn by boxers. It meant that the athlete could talk in a normal manner while the mouthguard was in place. In the January 1948 issue of the Journal of the American Dental Association, the procedure for making and fitting the acrylic mouthguard was described in detail by Dr. Lilyquist.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = | year = 1948 | title = Acrylic Splints for Athletes: Transparent Slip Casings for the Teeth as a Protection From Blows | url = | journal = Journal of the American Dental Association | volume = 36 | issue = 1| pages = 109–110 }}</ref> He immediately received nationwide recognition as the father of the modern mouthguard for athletes.<ref>"Protecting Athletes' Teeth." Pittsburgh Post-Gazette 21.162 (Feb. 6, 1948) 18.</ref> The first athlete to wear the acrylic mouthguard was a member of the UCLA basketball team, Dick Perry, who modeled the device at a convention of the Southern California Dental Association. Another early wearer was Frankie Albert, quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers. [[File:Football mouthguard.jpg|thumb|American Football mouthguard]] In the 1940s and 1950s, dental injuries were responsible for 24-50% of all injuries in American football.<ref name="Knapik et al., 2007, p. 121"/> In 1952, Life magazine did a report on [[Notre Dame football]] players without incisors.<ref>The fighting Irish look tough again. Life Magazine 1952; 33: 60-63.</ref> The article drew a lot of public attention and led to the inclusion of mouthguards in other contact sports. In the 1950s, the [[American Dental Association|American Dental Association (ADA)]] began researching mouthguards and soon promoted their benefits to the public.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = | year = 2006 | title = Using Mouthguards to Reduce the Incidence and Severity of Sports-related Oral Injuries | url = | journal = Journal of the American Dental Association | volume = 137 | issue = 12| pages = 1712–1720 | doi=10.14219/jada.archive.2006.0118}}</ref> In 1960, the ADA recommended the use of latex mouthguards in all contact sports. By 1962, all high school football players in the United States were required to wear mouthguards. The [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA)]] followed suit in 1973 and made mouthguards mandatory in college football. Since the introduction of the mouthguard, the number of dental injuries has decreased dramatically.<ref name="Knapik, et al., 2007, p. 121">Knapik, et al., 2007, p. 121.</ref>
Mouthguards have become a standard in many sports. In addition to football, the NCAA currently requires mouthguards in [[ice hockey]], [[field hockey]], and [[lacrosse]]. The ADA shows that mouthguards are extremely effective in preventing facial injury in contact and non-contact sports. The ADA recommends mouthguards be used in 29 sports: [[acrobatics]], [[basketball]], [[bicycling]], [[boxing]], [[equestrianism|equestrian]], [[American football|football]], [[gymnastics]], [[team handball|handball]], ice hockey, [[inline skating]], lacrosse, [[martial arts]], [[racquetball]], [[rugby football]], [[shot putting]], [[skateboarding]], [[skiing]], [[skydiving]], [[soccer]], [[softball]], [[squash (sport)|squash]], [[surfing]], [[volleyball]], [[water polo]], [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]] and [[wrestling]].<ref name="Knapik, et al., 2007, p. 121"/>
==Types==
===Stock or ready made=== Manufactured in a pre-formed shape in various sizes but with nearly no adjustment to fit the user's mouth. The only adjustment possible is minor trimming with a knife or scissors.
===Mouth adapted or "boil and bite"=== A thermoplastic material manufactured in a pre-formed shape in various sizes that can be adapted to fit more closely to an individual's teeth and gums by heating and molding such as boiling then placing in the mouth. Some are now available that incorporate special fins within the fitting zones which increase retention and give an improved fit over traditional boil and bite mouth types. Guards are usually made of [[Ethylene-vinyl acetate]][http://www.freepatentsonline.com/5339832.html][http://www.freepatentsonline.com/4044762.html], commonly known as EVA. Some of the newer technologies offer an alternative, stronger thermo-polymer that allows for lower molding temperatures, below 140F to prevent burning by scalding hot water. This is the most popular mouthguard used by amateur and semi-professional sportsmen, providing adequate protection but relatively low comfort in comparison to the custom-made guard.<ref name="b-and-b">{{cite journal |vauthors=Zadik Y, Levin L |title= Does a free-of-charge distribution of boil-and-bite mouthguards to young adult amateur sportsmen affect oral and facial trauma? |journal=Dent Traumatol |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=69–72 |date=February 2009 |pmid=19208013 |doi=10.1111/j.1600-9657.2008.00708.x}}</ref>
===Custom-made=== [[File:Vacuum-form mouth guard.jpg|thumb|Vacuum form mouthguard made from an impression using dental alginate.]]
An impression of the user's teeth is used by specialist manufacturers to create a best-fit mouth protector. The impression may be obtained by using a specially designed impression kit that uses dental putty, or from a dentist who will take an impression in dental [[Alginic acid#Sodium alginate|alginate]] material. The resulting impression is sent to a lab that makes a guard from the impression. In the [[EU]], the guard must be sold with a [[CE mark]] and the guard must have passed an EC Type-Examination test, performed by an accredited European Notified Body. Applying a CE mark without such certification is a criminal offense.{{where?|date=October 2012}}
*'''Vacuum Form''' **Custom-made mouth guards using this type of machine produce single layer mouth guards **Fit not as good as pressure laminated but offers more protection than boil and bite *'''Pressure Laminated''' **Custom-made mouth guards using this type of machine produce multi-layer mouth guards **Offers superior fit, comfort and more protection *'''Impressionless''' **Made from a medical-grade thermo polymer, the guards are activated with hot (not boiling water) and create a custom comfort fit, completely unique to the shape of the mouth. **1.6 mm thin, Remoldable, Works with braces, Stays secure in mouth during the entire game or practice **Allows athletes to talk, breathe and drink naturally
===Dentistry=== [[File:Aufbissschiene.jpg|thumb|Occlusal splint]]
Occlusal splints (also called bite splints, bite planes, or night guards) are removable dental appliances carefully molded to fit the upper or lower arches of teeth.
They are used to protect tooth and restoration surfaces, manage mandibular (jaw) dysfunction [[Temporomandibular joint disorder|TMD]], and stabilize the jaw joints during [[occlusion (dentistry)|occlusion]] or create space prior to restoration procedures. People prone to nocturnal [[bruxism]], or nighttime clenching, as well as [[morsicatio buccarum]] may routinely wear occlusal splints at night. However, a meta-analysis of occlusal splints used for this purpose concluded "There is not enough evidence to state that the occlusal splint is effective for treating sleep bruxism. An indication of its use is questionable concerning sleep outcomes, but there may be some benefit with regard to [[tooth wear]]."<ref>{{cite journal|title=The effectiveness of occlusal splints for sleep bruxism | pmid=18364692 | doi=10.1038/sj.ebd.6400569 | volume=9 | issue=1 | year=2008 | journal=Evid Based Dent | pages=23 | last1 = Jagger | first1 = R}}</ref>
Occlusal splints are typically made of a heat-cured acrylic resin. Soft acrylic or light cured composite, or vinyl splints may be made more quickly and cheaply, but are not as durable, and are more commonly made for short-term use. Soft splints are also used for children because normal growth changes the fit of hard splints.
They cover all the teeth of the upper or lower arch, but partial coverage is sometimes used. Occlusal splints are usually used on either the upper or the lower teeth, termed maxillary splints or mandibular splints respectively, but sometimes both types are used at the same time. Maxillary splints are more common, although various situations favor mandibular splints.
Stabilizing or Michigan-type occlusal splints are generally flat against the opposing teeth, and help jaw muscle relaxation, while repositioning occlusal splints are used to reposition the jaw to improve occlusion.{{medical citation needed|date=March 2016}}
==Usage== *'''[[Dental trauma]]''' **Mouthguards are used in sports where deliberate or accidental impacts to the face and jaw may cause harm. Such impacts may occur in many sports including [[baseball]], [[boxing]], [[mixed martial arts]], [[puroresu]], [[Rugby football|rugby]], [[wrestling]], [[association football|football (soccer)]], [[gridiron football]], [[Australian football]], [[lacrosse]], [[basketball]], [[figure skating]], [[ice hockey]], [[underwater hockey]], [[field hockey]], [[water polo]], [[skiing]], and [[snowboarding]]. Mouthguards may also prevent or reduce harm levels of [[concussion]] in the event of an injury to the jaw.<ref>[http://www.nzda.org.nz/pub/index.php?id=43 NZ Dental Association advice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629063538/http://www.nzda.org.nz/pub/index.php?id=43 |date=2007-06-29 }}</ref><ref>[http://bjsm.bmj.com/cgi/content/extract/35/2/81 "Do mouthguards prevent concussion?"]</ref> In many sports, the rules of the sport make their use compulsory,<ref>[http://www.rugbysmart.co.nz/plan/protectiveequipment.html "...mouthguards became compulsory in 1997..."] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20051202015904/http://www.rugbysmart.co.nz/plan/protectiveequipment.html |date=2005-12-02 }}</ref> or local health laws demand them. Schools also often have rules requiring their use.<ref>[https://www.oralmart.com/mouthguards-mandatory-for-basketball-wrestling-teams-middle-upper-schools/ "...mouthguards will be mandatory for all basketball and wrestling teams in the middle and upper schools...."]</ref> Studies in various high risk populations for [[Teeth|dental]] injuries are repeatedly reporting of a low [[Compliance (medicine)|compliance]] of individuals for the regular using of mouthguard during activities.<ref name="PREVENTION">{{cite journal |vauthors=Zadik Y, Jeffet U, Levin L |title=Prevention of dental trauma in a high-risk military population: the discrepancy between knowledge and willingness to comply |journal=Mil Med |volume=175 |issue=12 |pages=1000–1003 |date=December 2010 |pmid=21265309 |doi=10.7205/MILMED-D-10-00150}}</ref> Moreover, even with regular use, effectiveness in prevention on [[dental trauma]] is not complete, and injuries can still occur even when mouthguards are used as users are not always aware of the best makes or size, which inevitably result in a poor fit.<ref name="ELITE">{{cite journal |vauthors=Zadik Y, Levin L |title=Orofacial injuries and mouth guard use in elite commando fighters |journal=Mil Med |volume=173 |issue=12 |pages=1185–1187 |date=December 2008 |pmid=19149336 |doi=10.7205/milmed.173.12.1185}}</ref> *'''[[Oral medicine]]''' **Mouthguards may be used as [[splint (medicine)|splints]] to reduce strain over the [[temporomandibular joint]] in [[temporomandibular joint disorder]]{{medical citation needed|date=February 2013}} **To prevent tooth attrition in [[bruxism]]{{medical citation needed|date=February 2013}} **To deliver topical medication (e.g., [[corticosteroids]]) for chronic gingival diseases such as [[mucous membrane pemphigoid]].{{medical citation needed|date=February 2013}} **As a therapeutic device in the treatment of [[morsicatio buccarum]].<ref name="OMF pathology textbook">{{cite book|author=Brad W. Neville |author2=Douglas D. Damm|author3=Carl M. Allen|author4=Jerry E. Bouquot|title=Oral & maxillofacial pathology|year=2002|publisher=W.B. Saunders|location=Philadelphia|isbn=0721690033|pages=253–254|edition=2nd}}</ref> *'''Dental aesthetics''' **During [[tooth bleaching]]{{medical citation needed|date=February 2013}} **As a night protector of thin porcelain bridges{{medical citation needed|date=February 2013}} *'''[[Orthodontics]]''' **[[Invisalign]], a substitute for brackets and [[acryl group|acrylic]] plates{{medical citation needed|date=February 2013}} *'''[[Sleep medicine]]''' **Two types of mouthguards, the mandibular advancement device (MAD)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Quinnell|first1=Timothy G.|title=A crossover randomised controlled trial of oral mandibular advancement devices for obstructive sleep apnoea-hypopnoea (TOMADO)|journal=Thorax|date=17 July 2014|volume=2014|issue=69|pages=938–945|doi=10.1136/thoraxjnl-2014-205464|url=http://thorax.bmj.com/content/69/10/938|display-authors=etal}}</ref> and the tongue stabilizing device (TSD), are used for treating sleep apnea and snoring<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kerton|first1=James|title=Do As Seen On TV Snoring Mouthpieces Really Work?|url=http://www.topsnoringmouthpieces.com/do-as-seen-on-tv-snoring-mouthpieces-really-work/|publisher=Top Snoring Mouthpieces|accessdate=24 March 2016}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Sports|Dentistry}} *[[Dental trauma]]
==References== * [http://www.nature.com/bdj/journal/v186/n5/full/4800069a.html "Tooth surface loss; Part 3: Occlusion and splint therapy"] ''British Dental Journal'', Vol. 186, No. 5, 1999-03-13, via nature.com. Retrieved on 2007-08-18. * Widmalm, Sven E. [http://sitemaker.umich.edu/widmalm/files/bsconstruc.pdf "Bite Splints in General Dental Practice"], (Website, lectures from author's homepage), University of Michigan, 2003-11-14. Retrieved on 2007-08-19. * Widmalm, Sven E. [http://sitemaker.umich.edu/widmalm/files/useabusebs.pdf "Use and Abuse of Bite Splints"], (Website, lectures from author's homepage), University of Michigan, 2004-10-27. Retrieved on 2007-08-19.

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Patriotas | image = File:Patriotas logo.png | fullname = Patriotas Boyacá S.A. | founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2003|02|18}} | ground = [[Estadio La Independencia]],
[[Tunja]], Colombia | capacity = 21,000 | chairman = Juan Manuel Rogelis | manager = Diego Corredor | league = [[Categoría Primera A]] | season = [[2018 Categoría Primera A season#Torneo Finalización|2018–II]] | position = 15th | website = http://www.patriotasboyaca.co/ |pattern_la1 = _Patriotas2018h |pattern_b1 = _Patriotas2018h |pattern_ra1 = _Patriotas2018h |pattern_sh1 = _Patriotas2018h |pattern_so1 = |leftarm1 = A03853 |body1 = DF0D12 |rightarm1 = A03853 |shorts1 = DF0D12 |socks1 = DF0D12 |pattern_la2 = _Patriotas2018a |pattern_b2 = _Patriotas2018a |pattern_ra2 = _Patriotas2018a |pattern_sh2 = _Patriotas2018a |pattern_so2 = |leftarm2 = 2D7752 |body2 = 48B54B |rightarm2 = 2D7752 |shorts2 = 48B54B |socks2 = 2D7752 }} '''Patriotas Fútbol Club''', also known as '''Patriotas Boyacá''', is a professional Colombian [[Association football|football]] team based in [[Tunja]], that currently plays in the [[Categoría Primera A]]. They play their home games at the [[Estadio La Independencia|La Independencia]] stadium. ==History== Patriotas was founded in 2003 by the then-governor of [[Boyacá Department|Boyacá]] Miguel Ángel Bermúdez, together with then [[Coldeportes]]' chairman and the owners of hardware business G&J. In its first year in the [[Categoría Primera B|Primera B]], the club reached the semifinals, where was eliminated by [[Boyacá Chicó F.C.|Bogotá Chicó]]. In 2004 the team advanced again to the Semifinals, where the team played against [[Deportivo Antioquia]], [[Centauros Villavicencio]] and [[Tigres F.C.|Expreso Rojo]], but did not qualify. In 2005 Patriotas was second in the general table but in the Semifinals was eliminated by [[Rionegro Águilas|Bajo Cauca]]. In 2009 some changes were implemented in the tournament. Patriotas was first in Group B but was eliminated again in the Semifinals and ended up in third place. In 2011 the team was promoted to the [[Categoría Primera A]] after beating [[América de Cali]] by penalties. In 2016, the team qualified for the Knockout phase for the first time, after placing 8th in the First Stage.{{cite web|url=https://www.publimetro.co/co/noticias/2016/11/20/clasificados-8-liga-aguila-millonarios-santa-fe-medellin-cali-atletico-nacional-tolima-patriotas-bucaramanga.html|title=Millonarios y Patriotas, entre los 8 que disputarán la Liga Águila|author=|date=|website=Publimetro Colombia|accessdate=23 April 2018}} That year, the team also managed to qualify for the [[2017 Copa Sudamericana]], which was the first participation of the team in an international competition, reaching the second stage.{{cite web|url=http://caracol.com.co/radio/2016/12/05/deportes/1480947897_884827.html|title=Harold Rivera no continuará en la dirección técnica del Patriotas|first=Caracol|last=Radio|date=|website=Caracol Radio|accessdate=23 April 2018}} ==Honours== *'''[[Categoría Primera B]]:''' ::Runners-up (1): [[2011 Categoría Primera B season|2011]] ==Performance in CONMEBOL competitions== {| class="wikitable" ! {{Infobox stadium | name = Pavilhão da Cidadela | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Pavilhão da Cidadela.png | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Complexo Desportivo da Cidadela]]
[[Luanda]] | coordinates = {{coord|-8.826019|13.255271|type:landmark|display=title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = State-owned | operator = | surface = Hardwood | scoreboard = Electronic | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 6,873 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Atlético Petróleos de Luanda (basketball)|Petro de Luanda]] | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} '''Pavilhão da Cidadela''' is an Angolan [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arena]] located in [[Luanda]], [[Angola]]. The capacity of the arena is 6,873 people. It is used to host the [[Atlético Petróleos Luanda (basketball)|Atlético Petróleos Luanda]] and formerly of the [[Angola national basketball team]] before the appearance of [[Pavilhão Multiusos do Kilamba]]. ==2013 incident== The arena was the site of a deadly stampede on 1 January 2013 during a New Year vigil for believers of the [[Igreja Universal do Reino de Deus]], which killed 10 people and injured over 120 more.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20885821 |publisher=BBC News |title=Angola vigil crush at Luanda stadium kills 10}} ==See also== * [[Pavilhão Anexo]] * [[Pavilhão Anexo II]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Atlético Petróleos de Luanda}} {{Indoor arenas in Africa}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pavilhao da Cidadela}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Angola|Luanda]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Luanda]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Angola]] [[Category:Sport in Luanda]] {{Angola-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Use British English|date=March 2016}} '''Richard Purchase''' (1757 – 1837) was an English [[cricket]]er who played for the [[Hambledon Club]].
He was only 16 when he made his debut in 1773.
Born in [[Liss]], [[Hampshire]], he played for his county in 1773 and 1774 but then did not appear again until 1781. He was possibly in the armed forces at the time or otherwise working away from Hampshire.
He was an all-rounder noted as a slow bowler who maintained good line and length and a "fair hitter". He played regularly from 1781 till the end of his career in 1803, making 113 known first-class appearances.
==External links== * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010153250/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1771.html#purchase |date=10 October 2012 |title=From Lads to Lord's – profile }}
==References== * ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'' by [[G B Buckley]] (FL18) * ''The Dawn of Cricket'' by [[H T Waghorn]] (WDC) * ''Scores & Biographies, Volume 1'' by [[Arthur Haygarth]] (SBnnn) * ''The Glory Days of Cricket'' by [[Ashley Mote]] (GDC) * ''John Nyren's "The Cricketers of my Time"'' by [[Ashley Mote]]

revision.comment: Correction: You have the statue of ,"chief running fair" as destroyed by hurricane Sandy and no longer there, it is still standing and display at Riverhead raceway as I see it on the way to work eachday.
revision.text:
{{Motorsport venue |Name = Riverhead Raceway |Nicknames = |Time = GMT-5 |Location = [[Riverhead (CDP), New York|Riverhead]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |Coordinates = {{coord|40|55|21|N|72|42|16|W|region:US_type:landmark}} |Image = |Image_caption = |Capacity = |Owner = Eddie and Connie Partridge |Operator = |Broke_ground = 1949 |Opened = 1951 |Closed = |Construction_cost= |Architect = |Former_names = |Events = '''[[Whelen All-American Series]]'''
'''[[Whelen Modified Tour]]'''
'''[[Northeastern Midget Association]]''' |Layout1 = Oval |Surface = Asphalt |Length_km = .402 |Length_mi = .25 |Miles_first = true |Turns = 4 |Banking = }} '''Riverhead Raceway''' is a quarter-mile (400 m) oval [[race track]] with a [[Figure 8 racing|Figure 8]] course, located in [[Riverhead (CDP), New York|Riverhead]], [[New York (state)|New York]].http://localracing.nascar.com/node/176 It is the only [[auto racing]] venue on [[Long Island]] since Westhampton Raceway closed down in 2003.{{cite web | author= Paul Goldsmith|title= Gauge Nears 'E' at Riverhead Raceway| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2003/08/31/nyregion/gauge-nears-e-at-riverhead-raceway.html| work= [[The New York Times]]| publisher= | date= 2003-08-13| accessdate=2009-04-05}} It started being built in 1949 and opened as a dirt track in 1951, before permanently changing to [[asphalt]] in 1955.{{cite web | last= Lubin| first= Marshall| title= Memories and legends come alive at Riverhead Raceway| url= http://www.exploreli.com/entertainment/localguide/pine_barrens/ny-lifold034916467oct03,0,5465971.story| work= [[Newsday]]| publisher= exploreli.com| accessdate=2009-04-15 }} The Raceway was also well known for featuring a towering statue of a Native American, dubbed "Chief Running Fair", at its entrance until it was destroyed in 2012 due to Hurricane Sandy but rebuilt by Christmas and still standing at original location ==Events== Riverhead Raceway has seven racing divisions: [[Modified racing#Asphalt modifieds|Modified]], Riverhead Modified Crate [[Figure 8 racing|Figure Eight]], [[Late model#Racing|Late Model]], Blunderbust, Super Pro Truck, and [[Legends car racing|Legends]].[http://www2.timesreview.com/ST/stories/T051508_AUTO_BL The Suffolk Times][http://www2.timesreview.com/NR/stories/R052208_AUTO_BL The Riverhead News-Review] It hosts races for the [[Whelen All-American Series]], the [[Whelen Modified Tour]], and the [[Northeastern Midget Association]]. Other events include [[demolition derby]], school bus racing, [[monster trucks]], enduro, one-on-one spectator drags and [[go-karts]] up until the fall of 2016 . ==Drivers== Notable drivers who used to race at Riverhead Raceway include [[Greg Sacks]], [[Steve Park (NASCAR)|Steve Park]], [[Charlie Jarzombek]],[http://www.near1.com/HALL-OF-FAME/2004/Charlie_Jarzombek.htm Charlie Jarzombek] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009135411/http://www.near1.com/HALL-OF-FAME/2004/Charlie_Jarzombek.htm |date=2007-10-09 }}. [[New England Auto Racers Hall of Fame]]. Retrieved on 2008-04-15. [[Brett Bodine]], [[Tom Baldwin (NASCAR driver)|Tom Baldwin]], and [[Donny Lia]]. Bill Park, Steve Park's uncle, currently races at Riverhead Raceway.[http://www2.timesreview.com/NR/stories/R0508_AUTO_BL The Riverhead News-Review] And 2013 NASCAR Whelen Modified Tour champion [[Ryan Preece]] ==Riverhead Raceway Modified Champions== {|class="wikitable" !Year !Driver |- !2016 | Shawn Solomito |- ! 2015 | Tom Rogers Jr |- !2014 |Howie Brodie |- !2013 |Howie Brodie |- !2012 |Shawn Solomito |- !2011 |[[Justin Bonsignore]] |- !2010 |Tom Rogers Jr. |- !2009 |John Fortin |- !2008 |Bill Park |- !2007 |Bill Park |- !2006 |Chuck Steuer |- !2005 |Bill Park |- !2004 |Tom Rogers Jr. |- !2003 |John Fortin |- !2002 |J.R. revision.text:
'''[[Rugby union]] in [[Mozambique]]''' is a minor but growing sport.
==History== As a former Portuguese colony, rugby has been a late arrival to Mozambique. Although rugby has been played in Portugal for decades, it has never become a major sport, and it did not transfer it to its colonies.
[[Beira, Mozambique|Beira]] used to play a series against [[rugby union in Malawi|Nyasaland]] sides during the 1930s called the [[Woury Cup]].<ref>Bath, Richard (ed.) The Complete Book of Rugby (Seven Oaks Ltd, 1997 {{ISBN|1-86200-013-1}}) p71</ref>
Rugby is centred on the national capital and main city, [[Maputo]]. Mozambique's poverty and lack of infrastructure make it difficult to maintain a proper national league structure.
However, the country borders South Africa, where rugby is a major sport, and also neighbours Madagascar and Zimbabwe where the game is popular, as well as Malawi, Tanzania, and Zambia, all of which have had a historical rugby presence.
Rugby also has extensive TV coverage on satellite networks in Mozambique.<ref>http://www.travbuddy.com/travel-blogs/7106/Rugby-and-Saris-Nampula-72</ref>
==See also== * [[Mozambique national rugby union team]] * [[Confederation of African Rugby]] * [[Africa Cup]]
==External links== * [http://carugby.com/ CAR] * [http://wesclark.com/rrr/islamic_rugby.html "Islam and Rugby" on the ''Rugby Readers review'']
==References== <references/>
{{Rugby union outside WC}} {{Africa in topic|Rugby union in}} [[Category:Rugby union in Mozambique|*]] [[Category:Sport in Mozambique]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Servet Tazegül Arena
Servet Tazegül Spor Salonu | image =Sportshall in Mersin, Turkey.JPG | image_size =300px | location = [[Yenişehir, Mersin|Yenişehir]], [[Mersin]], [[Turkey]] |coordinates = {{coord|36|47|18|N|34|33|01|E|type:landmark_scale:100000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = January 20, 2012 | opened = {{start date and age|2013}} | owner = | operator = | construction_cost = | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 7,500 |Official_website = }} The '''Servet Tazegül Arena''' ({{lang-tr|Servet Tazegül Spor Salonu}}) is a multi-purpose [[indoor arena]] located at [[Yenişehir, Mersin|Yenişehir]] district of [[Mersin]], [[Turkey]], named in honor of the Olympic, world and European champion [[taekwondo]] practitioner [[Servet Tazegül]] (born 1988).{{cite web |url=http://www.mersin2013.gov.tr/detay/7481/Mersin-Tesisleri-ile-Fark-Yaratacak- |publisher=Mersin 2013 XVII Akdeniz Oyunları |title=Mersin, Tesisleri ile Fark Yaratacak... |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130507065909/http://www.mersin2013.gov.tr/detay/7481/Mersin-Tesisleri-ile-Fark-Yaratacak- |archivedate=2013-05-07 |df= }}{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/futbol/22801151.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |title=Akdeniz Oyunları için geri sayım |date=2013-03-13 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-14 }} The construction of the building began on January 20, 2012 with the laying of foundation stone.{{cite web |url=http://www.mersin2013.gov.tr/detay/5596/2013-Mersin-Icin-4-Buyuk-Tesis |publisher=Mersin 2013 XVII Akdeniz Oyunları |title=2013 Mersin İçin 4 Büyük Tesis |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-14 }} The arena is one of the eleven new-built sports venues in Mersin to host the [[2013 Mediterranean Games]].With its seating capacity of 7,500 , it is one of the biggest indoor arenas in Turkey. It is situated to the south of [[Mersin Tennis Complex]]. == 2013 Mediterranean Games== At [[2013 Mediterranean Games]], the arena hosted basketball event (men) between 17–25 June and volleyball semifinal and final events (women and men) between 27–30 June.{{cite web |url=http://www.mersin2013.gov.tr/detay/6817/Servet-Tazegul-Spor-Salonu |publisher=mersin 2013 |title=Servet Tazegül Spor Salonu |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-07-10 }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Venues of the 2013 Mediterranean Games}} {{Mersin Province}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Servet Tazegul Arena}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Turkey]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Turkey]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Turkey]] [[Category:Sports venues in Mersin]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2013]] [[Category:2013 Mediterranean Games venues]] [[Category:Yenişehir, Mersin]] {{Turkey-sports-venue-stub}}
