{{Infobox company | name = Sina Sports | logo = Sina sports logo.png | logo_size =175 | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | trading_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | romanized_name = | former_name = | type =Private | traded_as = | ISIN = | industry = [[Sports digital media]] | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = | founder = | defunct = <!-- {{end date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location = | hq_location_city = [[Beijing]] | hq_location_country = [[China]] | num_locations = | num_locations_year = <!-- Year of num_locations data (when known) --> | area_served = [[China]] | key_people = | products = Sina Sports website, mobile site, mobile app | brands = | production = | production_year = <!-- Year of production data (when known) --> | services = | revenue = | revenue_year = <!-- Year of revenue data (when known) --> | operating_income = | income_year = <!-- Year of operating_income data (when known) --> | net_income = <!-- or: | profit = --> | net_income_year = <!-- or: | profit_year = --><!-- Year of net_income/profit data (when known) --> | aum = <!-- Only for financial-service companies --> | assets = | assets_year = <!-- Year of assets data (when known) --> | equity = | equity_year = <!-- Year of equity data (when known) --> | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | members = | members_year = <!-- Year of members data (when known) --> | num_employees = 200 | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (when known) --> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | module = <!-- Used to embed other templates --> | website = {{URL|http://sports.sina.com.cn/}} | footnotes = <!-- Set positively ("true"/"yes"/etc) if company is international, otherwise omit -->}}
'''Sina Sports''' is a leading Chinese digital [[Sports journalism|sports media]] platform that provides live sporting events, highlights, news, discussion forums and other related sports content, primarily targeted at Chinese communities around the world. It is a subsidiary of Chinese internet company [[Sina.com]] and was established in 1998 as China's first online sports platform.
The platform operates an online website, mobile website, and mobile app, all of which are only available in the [[Chinese language]]. The mobile is available for iOS<ref>https://itunes.apple.com/cn/app/xin-lang-ti-yu/id564760110?mt=8</ref> and Android<ref>https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=cn.com.sina.sports</ref> devices. The platform also operates multiple verified SINA Weibo accounts including @新浪体育(@SINASports), @新浪体育视频(@SINASportsVideo), and others, collectively garnering over 20 million Weibo followers.<ref>{{cite web|title = SINA Sports Weibo|url = http://weibo.com/sportschannel|website = SINA Weibo|publisher = Sina.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = SINA Sports Video|url = http://weibo.com/sportsvideo|website = SINA Weibo}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = SINA NBA|url = http://weibo.com/nbachannel|website = SINA Weibo}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = SINA Competition|url = http://weibo.com/u/3083675110|website = SINA Weibo}}</ref>
== History == In 1998, Chinese Internet company SRSNet (四通利方) built and operated the official Chinese language online portal for the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]]. Later that year, [[SRSNet]] acquired Hua Yuan Online and changed the name to Sina.com, and the sports platform became known as SINA Sports.<ref>{{cite web|title = 新浪公司动态|url = http://corp.sina.com.cn/chn/sina_info_1998.html|website = corp.sina.com.cn}}</ref> From the beginning, Chinese sports fans quickly adopted the platform as a preferred way to access sports around the world. SINA Sports has had the following milestones<ref>{{cite web|title = 新浪公司动态|url = http://corp.sina.com.cn/chn/sina_info_1998.html|website = corp.sina.com.cn}}</ref> including:
* Official online website in China for FIFA 1998 * Official online partner in China for the 2000 Sydney Olympics * Exclusive Internet partner for the Chinese soccer team for FIFA 2002 * Official Internet partner for the Athens 2004 Olympics * Exclusive Internet partner in China for the 2008 Eurocup * First to provide live-streaming feed for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa
== Programming == Live Online Broadcasting Rights ([[Mainland China]]) as of November 2015:
=== European Football === SINA sports holds the live broadcasting rights for [[UEFA Champions League]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Sina Sports secures UEFA Champions League rights in China|url=http://en.ytsports.cn/news-1313.html?cid=0len=10style=0action=newslistpage=2str=tag:99order=0scid=|website=Yutang Sports}}</ref> [[AFC Champions League]], [[Premier League]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Sina, Tencent and LeTV claim Premier League rights deals|url=http://en.ytsports.cn/news-1140.html?cid=0len=10style=0action=newslistpage=2str=tag:99order=0scid=|website=Yutang Sports}}</ref> and [[Bundesliga]] games.
=== Domestic Football === SINA Sports holds the rights to broadcast [[Chinese Super League]] games.
=== Tennis === SINA Sports broadcasts the [[Women's Tennis Association|WTA]] Zhuhai,<ref>{{cite web|title=Sina Sports partners with 2015 WTA Elite Trophy|url=http://en.ytsports.cn/news-1258.html?cid=0len=10style=0action=newslistpage=2str=tag:99order=0scid=|website=Yutang Sports}}</ref> the [[China Open (tennis)|China Open]] and [[International Premier Tennis League]].<ref>http://en.ytsports.cn/news-1735.html?cid=1len=10style=0action=newslistpage=3order=falsescid=false</ref> It is also a partner of the [[Australian Open]].<ref>http://english.sina.com/sports/2016/0118/882830.html</ref>
=== Golf === SINA Sports holds the live broadcasting rights for the [[PGA Tour]] and [[the Masters]].
=== Others === Other rights include [[MUTV (Manchester United F.C.)|MUTV]],<ref>http://english.sina.com/sports/p/2016/0118/882546.html</ref> [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]],<ref>http://english.sina.com/sports/2016/0103/878258.html</ref> [[National Football League|NFL]], [[Dakar Rally]]<ref>http://english.sina.com/sports/2016/0112/880803.html</ref> and the [[Royal Ascot]].
== Recent Notable Campaigns == SINA Sports has developed many partnerships with international athletes.
=== Guest commentator program === Sina Sports signed several football personalities including [[Carlo Ancelotti]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Sina Sports announces exclusive content deal with Carlo Ancelotti|url=http://en.ytsports.cn/news-1225.html?cid=0len=10style=0action=newslistpage=2str=tag:99order=0scid=|website=Yutang Sports}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Ancelotti will comment the european football for Sina Sports - Carlo Ancelotti|url = http://www.carloancelotti.it/en/ancelotti-analizara-el-futbol-europeo-para-sina-sports/|website = Carlo Ancelotti|date = 2000-01-01|accessdate = 2015-12-14|language = en-US}}</ref> [[Eden Hazard]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Eden Hazard joins Sina Sport’s star squad|url=http://en.ytsports.cn/news-1548.html?wd=tag:99|website=Yutang Sports}}</ref> [[Gary Neville]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Sina Sports signs former captain of Manchester United|url=http://en.ytsports.cn/news-1540.html?wd=tag:99|website=Yutang Sports}}</ref> and [[Michael Owen]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Sina Sports signs former captain of Manchester United|url=http://en.ytsports.cn/news-1540.html?wd=tag:99|website=Yutang Sports}}</ref> to its guest commentator program to provide written columns and video analysis of the latest hot topics around European soccer as well as regular interaction with Chinese fans.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sina Sports signs former captain of Manchester United|url=http://en.ytsports.cn/news-1540.html?wd=tag:99|website=Yutang Sports}}</ref>
=== Kobe Bryant commentates NBA Championship live in China === For game 3 of the [[2015 NBA Finals]], SINA Sports arranged for [[Los Angeles Lakers]] player [[Kobe Bryant]] to commentate the game live for Chinese fans, which was streamed on the online and mobile sites. Kobe has his own SINA weibo account, which at the time had 3.5 million followers, sent out three messages during the game which garnered 9,347 comments. Overall, SINA reported 57 million unique views and 74,000 messages related to Kobe's commentating program were recorded on SINA Weibo.<ref>{{cite news|last1 = Yang|first1 = Tommy|title = Kobe Bryant analyzes Game 3 of NBA Finals for fans in China|url = http://www.latimes.com/sports/lakers/lakersnow/la-sp-ln-kobe-bryant-china-nba-finals-20150610-story.html|accessdate = 16 November 2015|publisher = Los Angeles Times|date = 10 June 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Multiple issues| {{Peacock|date=June 2009}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2018}}}} '''Tangolates''' (also known in Buenos Aires as '''Tango-Pilates''' and '''Pilates-Tango'''), involves body exercises that draw on characteristics from [[Tango (dance)|Tango dancing]] and [[Pilates]]. It utilizes a partner method rather than individual exercises and incorporates aerobic and cardio elements. Tangolates is usually performed on a specially designed apparatus, on a mat, or on a Pilates apparatus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.argentinaindependent.com/life-style/tango-pilates-tangolates/|title=The Argentina Independent|website=Argentinaindependent.com|accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elle.it/salute/benessere/news/a847845/tangolates/|title=Tangolates|date=9 November 2012|website=Elle.it|accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref>
==History== Tangolates originated in 2004 in a public hospital for patients with motor disorders.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} In order to help patients with their workouts, each one was coupled with an instructor in partner exercises.
==Research== In order to assess the effects of these exercises on patients, a preliminary test of efficacy was conducted at the Tamara Di Tella’s Pilates Room. The results of this research were presented at the 10th International Congress of Internal Medicine, held on 24-27 August 2004, in Buenos Aires.<ref>[http://www.uba.ar/comunicacion/p_electronicas/uu/anteriores/septiembre04/notas/02a.php] {{dead link|date=September 2018}}</ref>
Patients were convoked for 325 sessions, over a period of three months. Afterwards, patients asserted that the exercises helped them “not only to move better but also to feel better”. Their evaluations led to the conclusion that Tangolates partner exercises help patients improve, not only their movement but also their quality of life.
According to Di Tella, the fact that Tangolates requires a rapport between two people is a very interesting subject of research. Partner work may help stimulate the brain and could become an alternate pathway to successful movement. “It is that internal ignition that may just work for some brain disorder patients”, says Di Tella. Indeed, Tango’s strong and focused beat and the fact that it is done in close coordination with a partner is an excellent stimulus to initiate movement. “Tango stimulates cooperation and creates bond like no other dance, and this is an extraordinary motivator for some patients”, says Di Tella.
==Principles== Tangolates combines the coordination and core stability that is inherent to Pilates with the cardio or aerobic element of Tango.
==See also== * [[Tango (dance)|Tango]] * [[Pilates]] * [[Dance and health]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Books== *{{cite book|author= Pilates, Joseph |year=1928|title=Pilates' Return to Life Through Contrology |publisher=Presentation Dynamics (December 31, 1998)|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0-9614937-9-0}} *{{cite book|author=Blandine Calais-Germain|year=1993|title= Anatomy of Movement |publisher=Eastland Press|isbn=978-0-939616-17-6}} *{{cite book|author= Di Tella, Tamara |year=2005|title=Tangolates |publisher=Tamara Di Tella Pilates & Tangolates}} *{{cite book|author= Di Tella, Tamara |year=2003|title=Tamara Di Tella Pilates |publisher=Blue Series, LUMEN}}
==External links== *[http://www.tangolates.com Tamara Di Tella Tangolates]

page.title: Toronto Maple Leafs in popular culture

revision.text:
[[File:Hockey_Knights_in_Canada_Leafs.JPG|thumb|''Hockey Knights in Canada'' mural depicting the Leafs on the southbound side of Toronto's [[College station (Toronto)|College station]].]] The [[National Hockey League]] (NHL)'s '''[[Toronto Maple Leafs]]''' has been the point of subject for a number of media in [[Culture of Canada|Canadian]] '''[[popular culture]]''', including artworks, books, novels, and songs.
==Film== [[File:MikeMyersJune07.jpg|thumb|upright|Comedian [[Mike Myers]] has often included references to the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] in his films.]] References to the Toronto Maple Leafs have been made typically in association with the city of [[Toronto]], such as the case in the beginning of the 2010 spy film ''[[Fair Game (2010 film)|Fair Game]]''. During the scene, [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] agent [[Valerie Plame]] was being questioned by a suspicious weapons trafficker. He asks her if she is an American, and after responding that she is Canadian, he asks her about the Leafs. She replies that she is not a fan.<ref>{{cite news|last=Covert|first=Colin|title=Review: ‘Fair Game,’ a riveting real-life spy drama|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2010/11/03/review-fair-game-a-riveting-real-life-spy-drama/|newspaper=The Mercury News|publisher=First Digital Media|date=November 3, 2010|accessdate=February 26, 2018}}</ref>
The [[Canadiens–Maple Leafs rivalry|rivalry]] between the Maple Leafs and the [[Montreal Canadiens]] was also featured in the [[National Film Board of Canada]]'s adaptation of ''[[The Hockey Sweater]]'' by [[Roch Carrier]]. Completed a year after the book's publication, the [[National Film Board of Canada]] adapted the story into a ten-minute [[Animated cartoon|animated short film]] called ''The Sweater''. It was animated by [[Sheldon Cohen (artist)|Sheldon Cohen]] and voiced by Carrier.<ref name="CBCDigitalArchives">{{citation |url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/sports/hockey/the-spirit-of-hockey/the-hockey-sweater.html |title=The Hockey Sweater |publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=2013-01-03}}</ref> The film became one of the National Film Board's most popular works and has won numerous awards.<ref>{{citation |last=Marshall |first=Suzanne |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/articles/the-hockey-sweater |title=The Hockey Sweater |publisher=The Historica-Dominion Institute of Canada |accessdate=2013-01-03}}</ref> It was named the Best Animated Film at the [[35th British Academy Film Awards|1981]] [[British Academy Film Awards]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.bafta.org/awards-database.html?sq=The+Sweater |title=Awards Database: Film - Animated Film - 1981 |publisher=British Academy of Film and Television Arts |accessdate=2013-01-03}}</ref>
Another film where the hockey club was heavily featured was in ''[[Face-Off (1971 film)|Face-Off]]'', a Canadian film about a rookie Maple Leafs player and his romance with a musician. The film featured several players from the NHL, including [[Bobby Orr]], [[George Armstrong (ice hockey)|George Armstrong]], and [[Gordie Howe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metronews.ca/features/toronto/maple-leafs-playoffs-2013/2013/04/22/3-movies-inspired-by-the-toronto-maple-leafs.html|title=3 movies inspired by the Toronto Maple Leafs|publisher=Free Daily News Group Inc|work=Metro Toronto|accessdate=2 March 2018|last=Cross|first=Jessica Smith|date=April 22, 2013}}</ref> The 1993 film ''Gross Misconduct'' focused on the life of former Maple Leafs [[winger (ice hockey)|left wing]] [[Brian Spencer]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Gross Misconduct|publisher=IMDb|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107047/|accessdate=September 18, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110901160800/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107047/|archivedate=September 1, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The hockey club was also featured in the 2006 [[television documentary]] series ''[[Hockey: A People's History]]'', by the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]].
Comedian [[Mike Myers]], a fan, often included references and even an entire plot line in his films. In ''[[Austin Powers in Goldmember]]'', the ticker below the news item on a television reads, "Maple Leafs win Stanley Cup". In another scene, the character [[Mini-Me]] wears a Maple Leafs sweater.<ref>{{cite news|last=Granatstein|first=Rob|title=Myers is groovy, baby!|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Artists/M/Myers_Mike/2002/08/23/pf-760477.html|publisher=Canoe|date=August 22, 2002|accessdate=September 24, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120713161820/http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Artists/M/Myers_Mike/2002/08/23/pf-760477.html|archivedate=July 13, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In addition to the references included in several films, the Maple Leafs also played a central role in Myers' 2008 film ''[[The Love Guru]]'', where he played a guru hired to help the Maple Leafs' star player.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Love Guru|publisher=IMDb|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0811138/|accessdate=September 18, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110912033429/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0811138/|archivedate=September 12, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Literature== [[File:Roch Carrier as a child.jpg|thumb|[[Roch Carrier]], author of ''[[The Hockey Sweater]]'', as a child in a Maple Leafs sweater. ]] References to the Leafs in literature includes [[Foster Hewitt]] juvenile hockey novel, ''He Shoots, He Scores!''. Published in 1949, it featured the members of the team, including actual managers and players.<ref>{{cite book|title=He Shoots, he scores|last=Hewitt|first=Foster|year=1949|publisher=Thomas Allen}}</ref> In 1963, Scott Young wrote ''A Boy at the Leafs' Camp'', a children's book giving a behind-the-scenes insight into the sport.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Boy at the Leafs' Camp|publisher=Goodreads.com|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/2175182.A_Boy_at_the_Leafs_Camp|accessdate=September 18, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111020952/http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/2175182.A_Boy_at_the_Leafs_Camp|archivedate=November 11, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Several books concerning the Maple Leafs have been written, and later readapted into film. In 1971, Young and George Robertson co-wrote an adult hockey-romance novel, ''[[Face-Off (1971 film)|Face-off]]'', about the experiences of a star rookie player, Billy Duke, with the Leafs.<ref>{{cite book|title=Face-off|last1=Young|first1=Scott|last2=Robertson|first2=George|year=1971|publisher=MacMillan of Canada}}</ref> The novel became a movie in 1971 with [[Art Hindle]] as Billy Duke. The film featured many of the players. [[Jim McKenny]], body-doubled for Hindle for the on-ice action scenes because of his resemblance to Hindle. Owner Ballard had a part as the team doctor.<ref>{{cite web|title=Face-Off|publisher=IMDb|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0068564/|accessdate=September 18, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110828212606/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0068564/|archivedate=August 28, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 1979, [[Roch Carrier]] wrote the short story ''[[The Hockey Sweater]]'' about a Montreal Canadiens fan who is mistakenly sent a sweater of their rival, the Maple Leafs. Originally published in French as "''Une abominable feuille d'érable sur la glace''" ("An abominable maple leaf on the ice"), it referred to the Maple Leafs sweater a mother forced her son to wear.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/canadiens-versus-leafs-two-rivals-meet-again-but-theyve-changed/wcm/10396669-554f-42a1-b45e-99e84ec294a3|title=Canadiens versus Leafs: Two rivals meet again, but they’ve changed|date=April 6, 2012|accessdate=July 14, 2017|work=National Post|publisher=Postmedia Network Inc.|last=O'Connor|first=Joe}}</ref> The boy is forced to weat the sweater and faces persecution of his peers and coach, also fans of the Canadiens. The boy is presumably based on Carrier himself when he was young.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/3146716/carriers-the-hockey-sweater-still-captivates-70-years-after-winter-of-1946/|title=Carrier’s ‘The Hockey Sweater’ still captivates, 70 years after winter of 1946|last=Lowrie|first=Morgan|work=Global News|publisher=Corus Entertainment Inc.|date=December 24, 2016|accessdate=July 14, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170129080008/http://globalnews.ca/news/3146716/carriers-the-hockey-sweater-still-captivates-70-years-after-winter-of-1946/|archivedate=January 29, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 1980, the story was turned into an animated short by the [[National Film Board of Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Hockey Sweater|publisher=IMDb|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0134127/|accessdate=September 18, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321183859/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0134127/|archivedate=March 21, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> An excerpt of the book is featured on the Canadian five-dollar [[Canadian Journey Series|Canadian Journey]] bills, a series of banknotes issued from 2002 to 2013.
==Radio shows== In 1946, the comedy team of [[Wayne and Shuster]] performed a sketch on their CBC [[Radio programming|radio program]] in which the imaginary hockey team, the Mimico Mice, competed against the Leafs. Foster Hewitt provided the play-by-play of the game, with real player names used for the Leafs and Wayne and Shuster voiced the entire Mimico team.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wayne and Shuster: Canadian comedy act|publisher=The Museum of Broadcast Communications|author=Ross A. Eaman|url=http://www.museum.tv/eotvsection.php?entrycode=wayneandshu|accessdate=September 22, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807024301/http://www.museum.tv/eotvsection.php?entrycode=wayneandshu|archivedate=August 7, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Song== In the video for the hit [[Leo Sayer]] song “[[When I Need You]]” (1976), he walks on the beach in Brighton, U.K. wearing a Toronto Maple Leafs sweater under his half done-up jacket. In 1990 live videos for the song "F*!#in' Up", [[Neil Young]] sports a Toronto Maple Leafs jersey. In 1992, Canadian rock band [[The Tragically Hip]] released the song "[[Fifty Mission Cap]]", which memorialized [[Bill Barilko]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.pe.ca/living/the-fabulously-rich-a-tribute-to-the-tragically-hip-shares-frontmans-music-vision-for-truth-and-reconciliation-182525/|title=The Fabulously Rich, a tribute to The Tragically Hip, shares frontman’s music vision for truth and reconciliation|work=The Guardian|publisher=Saltwire Network|last=Cole|first=Sally|date=February 1, 2018|accessdate=February 26, 2018}}</ref> Barilko scored the series winning goal for the [[1950 Stanley Cup Finals]] before disappearing months later. On October 17, 2017, several days after the death of The Tragically Hip's lead singer [[Gord Downie]], the Maple Leafs held a [[moment of silence]] prior to their game, as well as lower the banner of Barilko's retired number.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/toronto-maple-leafs-remember-gord-downie-1.4361289|title=Maple Leafs honour Gord Downie before game at ACC|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=March 2, 2018|date=October 18, 2017|work=CBCNews Toronto|last=McLaughlin|first=Amara}}</ref>
==Visual art== [[College station (Toronto)|College station]] of the Toronto subway system feature a pair of murals called ''Hockey Knights in Canada'', named after ''[[Hockey Night in Canada]]''; one depicting the Toronto Maple Leafs on the southbound side and facing the Montreal Canadiens on the northbound side, depicting the [[Maple Leafs – Canadiens rivalry|decades-old rivalry between the two clubs]]. They were created by [[Charles Pachter]] in 1984, when the Toronto Maple Leafs still played at nearby [[Maple Leaf Gardens]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/leafs/2014/08/26/maple_leafs_from_hockey_knights_in_canada_to_legends_row.html|title=Maple Leafs: From Hockey Knights in Canada to Legends Row|publisher=thestar.com|date=26 August 2014}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Ice hockey in popular culture]]
